A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Torsion submodule to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine whether the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a torsion submodule, we need to analyze the components of the definition of a torsion submodule. The definition of a torsion submodule involves the concept of an A-module M, which is a mathematical structure that can be thought of as a set with additional algebraic operations defined on it. The torsion submodule T consists of all torsion elements of M, which implies that T is a subset of M. Since a subset is a specific type of set, the concept of a set is inherently used in defining what a torsion submodule is. Therefore, understanding and defining a torsion submodule relies on the concept of a set, as it involves dealing with collections of elements (subsets) within the module M.
